column4: Italy's Enel to sell green power to Kellogg in virtual wind farm deal

column6: The two companies said on Wednesday they had signed a 100 megawatt virtual power purchase agreement (VPPA) for electricity delivered into the grid from Enel’s Azure Sky wind-and-storage project in Texas.
column7: The amount is equal to half the electricity used by Kellogg in its manufacturing facilities across North America.
column8: The food producer, which is committed to having 100% green energy in its operations by 2050, said the deal would help it reach 50% of its global Better Days goal to reduce its Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions by 65%.
column9: “This... demonstrates to investors, stakeholders and our consumers that we are taking swift action to address climate change,” Kellogg’s Chief Sustainability Officer Amy Senter said.
column10: VPPAs are increasingly used by U.S. companies to bolster their green credentials and lock in prices for their energy.
column11: Supporters believe they can help accelerate a broader shift to clean energy sources by funding projects.
column12: Enel’s 350 MW wind farm in Texas, coupled with some 137 MW of battery storage, is the Italian utility’s third hybrid project in the United States and will start operation in the first half of next year.

column4: Packaged food giants push direct online sales to gauge consumer tastes
column5: (Reuters) - Packaged food giants including Kraft Heinz, General Mills and Kellogg are pushing sales of their products to consumers directly via their own online channels, in a quest to gather more data about shoppers’ purchasing habits.
column6: Velveeta-cheese maker Kraft Heinz saw its e-commerce sales double in 2020, now representing more than 5% of its global sales, Chief Executive Miguel Patricio said at the virtual Consumer Analyst Group of New York (CAGNY) conference this week.
column7: The company sells Heinz baked beans and tomato soup by subscription or in bundles directly to consumers on a “Heinz To Home” website in the United Kingdom, Australia and Europe.
column8: Sales on the site are “giving us valuable insights into consumer behavior, enabling us to quickly test and learn from innovations,” Kraft’s head of international business, Rafael de Oliveira, said at the conference.
column9: Kraft would continue to use the site as a channel to generate strong sales in developed markets, he said.
column10: The company also counts sales of its products through marketplaces such as on Amazon.com and Walmart.com as part of its e-commerce sales.
column11: U.S. shoppers spent on average $1,271 buying groceries online last year, 45% more than they did in 2019 as the pandemic spurred shopping online, according to market research firm Earnest Research. In contrast, the average dollars spent in stores rose only about 7% to $3,849.
column12: PepsiCo sells products including Doritos, Quaker oats and Gatorade directly to consumers through two websites, pantryshop.com and snacks.com, both launched in 2020.
column13: Chief Financial Officer Hugh Johnston said that more than 45% of the company’s capital investments over the next few years would be dedicated toward manufacturing capacity, automation, and a “ramping up of investments in our e-commerce channel.”
column14: As major online retailers including Amazon.com and Walmart.com continue to gather valuable data on shoppers, many packaged food manufacturers are keen to gather their own data on shoppers, too.
column15: “COVID (has) simply accelerated our digital growth and has provided us with yet another source of data and insight,” Monica McGurk, chief growth officer at breakfast cereal maker Kellogg Co., told the conference.
column16: Kellogg, producer of Corn Flakes as well as Pringles chips, said on Wednesday it had launched a direct-to-consumer website focused on digestive wellness. The group plans to sell its new Mwell Microbiome Powder for gut health via the site to gather data on customer interest before it launches the product more widely.
column17: E-commerce sales have doubled in the past year and now represent about 8.5% of the group’s $13.77 billion in annual sales, Kellogg said.
column18: Pillsbury dough-maker General Mills also sees the benefits of tracking consumer habits more closely.
column19: “We’re aggressively investing in data and analytics. We are gathering unparalleled insights from the first-party data we collect through our brand websites,” General Mills’ Chief Executive Jeffrey Harmening said at the conference.
column20: On its Bettycrocker.com website, General Mills provides hundreds of recipes using Betty Crocker cake mixes and frosting. The site leads people to the closest store or an online retailer where they can purchase the products, thereby generating data for General Mills on what a particular customer from a certain zip code is buying. The company does not sell the food products directly on its website.
column21: Consumers, however, may have to shell out more if they shop directly from brand websites.
column22: Prices on the two PepsiCo sites, for example, were generally higher than those on Walmart.com or Amazon.com, Reuters checks show. On Walmart.com, for example, a 10 oz pack of Doritos Nacho Cheese was on sale for $2.50 compared to $4.29 on Pepsico’s website.
column23: Kraft Heinz offers tins of soup, beans, pasta and baby food bundled into packs ranging from six to 25 items and costing between 10 and 20 pounds ($14.01-$28.03) on its UK website. It told Reuters the relatively higher prices of items and bundling of packs than on some other online marketplaces was to be able to eke out a margin after including delivery costs.
column24: “Longer term, we see real value in this channel to be an insight and data channel for us,” Jean-Philippe Nier, head of e-commerce for Kraft Heinz’s business in the UK and Ireland, told Reuters. People are more prepared to order directly from manufacturers than they were before. The time is now.”

column6: People who had resorted to eating at home during the height of the pandemic have cut purchases of frozen foods and ready-to-eat snacks and returned to ordering in.
column7: While demand for packaged foods has stayed elevated into the current quarter, they are below the levels seen during the panic-buying stage.
column8: Additionally, higher costs have been weighing on packaged food companies. Breakfast cereal maker Kellogg earned 85 cents per share, below estimates of 89 cents, hurt by higher spending on advertising and promotions, as well as COVID-related costs.
column9: Kellogg’s shares, which declined about 10% in 2020, were marginally down in morning trading.
column10: Packaged foods makers have been pouring millions into their supply chains to meet heightened demand from grocers as they look to become bigger players in a competitive food space, while also spending more on hygiene and sanitation measures.

column4: Kellogg's earnings outlook softened by Keebler sale, shares fall
column5: CHICAGO (Reuters) - Breakfast cereal maker Kellogg K.N on Thursday forecast full-year earnings that widely missed market expectations, hurt by the sale of its Keebler cookie business and other assets to Nutella maker Ferrero SpA.
column6: Shares in Battle Creek, Michigan-based Kellogg declined 7.9%in morning trading.
column7: Kellogg, which also makes Pringles, Cheez-Its and Pop-Tarts, said it expected adjusted earnings per share to decline by between 3% and 4% in 2020, falling short of the 3.8% increase analysts had expected, according to Refinitiv.
column8: “When you look where expectations were, there was probably not a full appreciation for the magnitude of the divestiture in our results,” Kellogg Chief Executive Steve Cahillane said in an interview.
column9: Over the past year, the Battle Creek, Michigan-based company has undergone a restructuring, hoping to revitalize its business and attract health-conscious consumers who are not buying the sugary cereals that were once a staple of American breakfast tables. In April, Kellogg sold Keebler and its fruit-flavored snacks, pie crusts and ice-cream cones businesses to Ferrero for $1.3 billion so it could focus on its core cereals and snacks businesses.
column10: The market became increasingly positive about Kellogg in recent months because it expected a return to earnings growth, Wells Fargo analyst John Baumgartner wrote in a note, adding that the big miss suggests larger first-half divestiture costs or weaker underlying profitability.
column11: The divestments also hurt fourth-quarter sales, which declined 2.8% to $3.22 billion.
column12: Kellogg reported a net income attributable to itself of $145 million compared with a loss of $84 million a year earlier. In the comparative quarter, earnings were hurt by a strong dollar, the costs of an ongoing restructuring and preparations for Brexit.
column13: Excluding items, Kellogg earned 91 cents per share in the fourth quarter, ended Dec. 28, beating analysts expectations of 85 cents per share, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column14: Kellogg has over the past year amped up spending on promotions and advertising, while making snack-pack versions of classic products that appeal to on-the-go shoppers.

column4: UPDATE 1-Can global corporations meet 2020 no-deforestation pledge?
column5: (Updates with fresh information & comment from Kellogg Co)
column6: KUALA LUMPUR, Nov 15 (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - After becoming a target for high-profile campaigns against tropical forest loss by environmentalists, global household brands that buy and use palm oil agreed in 2010 to ensure their supplies did not contribute to deforestation within a decade.
column7: The 400 members of the Paris-based Consumer Goods Forum said they would purchase only sustainably produced commodities including palm oil, soy, paper and pulp, and beef.
column8: The landmark pledge did not specify whether the deadline should be January or December of 2020, and allowed each firm to set its own precise dates to reach the goal.
column9: The Thomson Reuters Foundation asked 12 multinational CGF members over the past month if they were sticking to the 2020 pledge to halt deforestation and whether it would be met.
column10: Five indicated the 2020 deadline would likely be missed, while at least four others did not say whether it would be achieved.
column11: Here are responses from the companies:
column12: 1. CARGILL INC: In June, commodities trader Cargill said it, and the broader food industry, would fail to meet the goal of eliminating deforestation by 2020 and pledged to do more to protect forests and native vegetation in Brazil.
column13: A spokeswoman said last month that Cargill remained committed to delivering a fully transparent, traceable and sustainable palm oil supply chain by 2020.
column14: 2. DANONE: In its latest palm oil update here, the French food group said it was committed to eliminating deforestation from its supply chain by the end of 2020.
column15: The company is working with green group Earthworm and has put in place a traceability system allowing it to map its supply chain each year.
column16: 3. FERRERO: The Italian confectioner met its target of using 100% sustainable certified palm oil in all its products in January 2015, a spokesperson said.
column17: Ferrero's palm oil charter here also states the company is committed to ensuring its suppliers do not use fire to clear land or plant palm on peatland, and that they respect human and labour rights.
column18: 4. GENERAL MILLS INC: The Cheerios cereal-maker said it achieved its goal here to source 100% of its palm oil from responsible and sustainable sources in 2015.
column19: In 2018, the company made public its global palm oil suppliers’ list which is updated each year.
column20: 5. JOHNSON & JOHNSON: The U.S. healthcare conglomerate's responsible palm oil-sourcing criteria here stresses the importance of social and environmental responsibility, and transparency.
column21: It said it was committed to implementing those criteria across its top palm oil suppliers “representing at least 85 percent of our volume by year-end 2020”.
column22: 6. KELLOGG CO: The company is a small user of ingredients and materials that have high deforestation risks, said Amy Senter, chief sustainability officer.
column23: “Progress has been made since the CGF deforestation resolution was passed in 2010, but like others, we will fall short of the deforestation goal,” she said.
column24: “We are actively applying the learnings over the past decade toward strategic shifts in supply chain engagement and collaborative, holistic partnerships,” she added.
column25: The breakfast-foods and snack-maker's website here says it is "committed to help achieve zero net deforestation from tropical forests" and 99% of its palm oil here purchases are from sustainably certified suppliers.
column26: 7. MARS: In a policy here, the chocolate-maker says it aims to "deliver 100% deforestation-free palm oil by the end of 2020", according to a spokeswoman.
column27: The policy states that Mars plans to simplify and verify its supply chain by reducing the number of its supplier mills from more than 1,500 to less than 100 by the end of next year.
column28: 8. MONDELEZ INTERNATIONAL: Since 2014, the snack-maker has required its palm oil suppliers to convert their entire supply chains - regardless of the end customer - to sustainable practices, said Christine Montenegro McGrath, its chief of global impact, sustainability and well-being.
column29: The company supports and encourages the sector-wide approach being pioneered by the CGF, she added, but did not provide details on whether Mondelez would meet the 2020 pledge.
column30: In a statement here on its website, the firm said one of its goals was to "maintain 100% RSPO (Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil) palm oil (and) 100% palm oil traceable to the mill from suppliers with aligned policies".
column31: 9. NESTLE: The food giant, which makes KitKat bars and Haagen-Dazs ice cream, said in September it would likely fall short of the 2020 target.
column32: By April, 77% of key agricultural commodities the company buys - including soy and palm oil - were verified as deforestation-free, a spokeswoman said, adding this would top 90% by the end of 2020.
column33: To stamp out deforestation along its supply chain, Nestle uses a combination of certification, supply chain mapping, on-the-ground verification and satellite surveillance, she added.
column34: Nestle would continue to work with smallholder farmers and large suppliers to get close to being entirely free of deforestation within the next three years, she said, citing the company's no-deforestation commitment here.
column35: 10. PEPSICO INC: The beverage and snack maker's global policy here on sustainable palm oil includes goals for no deforestation or peatland development and achieving 100% RSPO certified sustainable palm oil by the end of 2020, a spokeswoman said.
column36: 11. PROCTER & GAMBLE CO: The personal care products maker, which uses palm oil in its Tide detergent and Olay skincare lines, said in September it would fail to meet the zero deforestation goal by next year.
column37: "We have met our commitment to get to 100% RSPO certified palm oil and ensuring 100% certified virgin wood pulp in our tissue towel products," a company spokeswoman said, citing the latest report here.
column38: 12. UNILEVER: The consumer goods giant's 2020 commitments have not changed, said a spokeswoman, citing two company reports on sustainable palm oil here and zero deforestation here. The firm was "on track" to meet next year's deadline, she added.
column39: "We're the world's largest single buyer of palm oil – purchasing 3% of global production each year – so we're focusing on playing a leadership role in breaking the link between palm oil production and deforestation," the company's website says.
